turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: You might see her. She writes your Daddy, and she and that doctor came to see him, didn't they? I wish you'd tell her something... I never could write letters.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: What do you want me to tell her, Dave?

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: Oh, to hell with it, never mind. Don't tell her anything. Don't even tell her you saw me.  Got to run, Buddy, I'll miss my plane.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: I don't like that, either, it's worse than Waski. I want to be called Fran.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Daddy wouldn't hear that. Now the redhaired boy you see sitting there, of course you have met him, he is my oldest son and my most brilliant child. All children have great creative powers, but I don't want to rattle on about my children, they say I brag too much about them, especially about Brother. Am I boring you, Rose?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Yes, dear, what is it?

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: Mother, Buddy says Rose got in his bed last night and he fiddled with her and she snorted and had a fit -- and he says I would too if I was grown-up. Is it true, Mother -- would I sweat and snort and froth at the mouth and have a horrible fit like he says?

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: Daddy, Buddy was up late last night reading little dirty comic books. Mother gave him a dose of castor oil and he cursed it, he took the Lords name in vain, then claimed he hadn't said it. He lied, Daddy.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: You mustn't be a tattletale, dear. You mustn't be Delilah-ish and Jezebel-ish toward your brother, dear.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: I'm only trying to help him, Mother.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: What's the matter with him?

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: I don't know. I think he's cryin'!

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: Well, Mrs. Hillyer, the girl is strong as an ox and that is what is keeping her alive. But not many people walk away from double pneumonia, Madam, not many.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: She looks terrible, just awful.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: Of course she does and I must say I'm puzzled by your delay in getting her to the hospital. I should think ordinary powers of observation would have suggested to you that she was seriously ill.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: She hid it from us, Doctor. She's afraid of the hospital.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: Afraid of the hospital?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Deathly afraid of it. Her people were poor tenant farmers and she doesn't know anything about doctors or medicine or hospitals.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: A tenant farm? Are you trying to tell me that girl is a product of the hookworm and pellagra belt?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well, her people were very poor. She says she was often hungry as a child, and I'm sure the food she ate was pretty awful, not a balanced diet at all.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: Exactly, and that's why she couldn't possibly have come from such a farm.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: It's simply that I find it incredible, Mr. Hillyer. Aside from the girl's illness at the moment, she is very strong, a very healthy specimen of a young human female -- and a comely one, too. She must have gotten protein somewhere as a young child, if only sporadically.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: It is kind of amazing. The dentist says she has perfect teeth, there isn't a cavity in her mouth.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Yes, thank you, Doctor.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: I beg your pardon, epi-zoo-tics? Do you mean "epi-zoo-ot-tics," an animal epidemic?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Oh, good evening, Doctor. Rose is a lot better, I just gave her her supper. She's almost all well now.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: Let me be the judge of that, Madam.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Yes. Well. She's upstairs.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: I'm not surprised you thought she was pregnant. An ovarian cyst can look very much like pregnancy. But it was pure wishful thinking on her part. The girl can never have children, she had gonorrhea at fifteen and it was untreated.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Gonorrhea?

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: Don't worry, Madam, she can't infect your dear little kiddies. She long ago fully recovered, but the disease did irreparable damage. The girl is permanently barren.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well, that's pathetic. Poor Rose, what a life she has had.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: We make our own lives, Madam. As for malignancy, I don't think so, it's very unlikely. I probably shouldn't have even mentioned that possibility to her.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: No, you shouldn't have, it was needlessly cruel. She thinks she has cancer and is going to die.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: She's an adult, Mrs. Hillyer, I was merely giving her the facts.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: I'm sorry the truth nauseates you, Mrs. Hillyer, because before you leave there's a bit more of it I'd like to put to you. This operation provides a therapeutic opportunity that I feel is quite important in regard to this particular girl, who suffers not only from an ovarian cyst but from a certain psychoneurotic condition as well.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: What do you mean, what kind of gobbledygook talk is that?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Yes, go on.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: I am thinking particularly of the other ovary. As a rule I don't believe in removing it. The woman's hormonal system is profoundly disturbed, she is subject to possibly serious depression, she loses many of her secondary sexual characteristics for example, her breasts might shrink and become flabby, facial hair might appear along with a coarsening of the features, and of course her sexual drive is greatly diminished, especially in a girl or young woman. For these reasons I am opposed to removing the other ovary, as a rule. Do you follow me?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: What are you talking about? I don't understand all this mumbo jumbo and the funny looks on your faces.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: Mrs. Hillyer, this girl is sick in more ways than one. She is an extreme psychoneurotic with uncontrollable sexual impulses. It would be a mercy to spare her the suffering she causes herself and others. Therefore I recommend as a therapeutic measure the removal of her second ovary. It is ethically and medically the only proper decision in this case and I suspect your husband agrees with me.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Are you human beings or are you some kind of male monsters? Is there no limit to which you won't go to keep your illusions about yourselves?

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: Illusions, Madam?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: You'd go so far as to mutilate a helpless girl who has no means to defend herself, you'd go that far? Don't you think I know what you've just said and don't you think I understand the dreadful and revolting crime you've just conspired to commit?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I will not cry like a woman. If I'm upset it's because of what my husband said, not because of you. You can't make me cry like a woman, a woman has got just as much intelligence and self-control as a man. And you get this in your head. If you hurt that girl, I'll hire lawyers and sue you for malpractice for every penny you have got, I'll do my level best to ruin you. Do you understand me?

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: Yes, I understand you, but you have misunderstood me completely.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I understand you perfectly. You leave that girl alone, you wretched man, or you will be sorry.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: Actually of course I won't operate, I don't do major surgery. Dr. Hardy will operate and of course he'll be guided by your wishes in this respect.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Let him be guided not by my wishes and not by Rose's wishes, although I am sure they are identical. Let him be guided by the wishes of the creative power of life itself, because that is what has spoken through me tonight.

turns.speaker: DR. WINTON
turns.text: Well, she finally let me look in her mouth. Is it true she's never been to a dentist?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: She was raised on a poor dirt farm. I'm sure she's never seen a dentist or hardly even a doctor.

turns.speaker: DR. WINTON
turns.text: Well, she has one mouth in ten thousand, I don't see teeth like that once in ten years. Her trouble is an impacted wisdom tooth, but there isn't a cavity in her head, not a single one. She has perfect teeth.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: But the wisdom tooth will have to be pulled?

turns.speaker: DR. WINTON
turns.text: Yes, and it's very bad. It probably should be done at the hospital under general anesthesia.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: That would scare her to death. She's terrified of hospitals. To her, a hospital is where you go to die.

turns.speaker: DR. WINTON
turns.text: I think you're right, it would be harder on her. But you'd better call Mr. Hillyer, she's going to need help to get home.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Rose, this is Waski. His real name is Warren but we call him Waski. He doesn't like it much and I suppose someday we'll have to stop calling him that.

turns.speaker: WASKI
turns.text: You can stop it right now.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: When he was baby we called him "Wa Wa," a baby name, you know. You will find him a very good boy. His brother can be bad and so can his sister, but Waski is a very good boy. And as you can see he's beautiful.

turns.speaker: WASKI
turns.text: Oh, Mother, cut it out.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: There are plenty of girls who would give thousands of dollars to have your auburn hair. Beauty is beauty and that's all there is to it. Beauty is there and we have to recognize it. Now Rose, the little girl sitting across from you with the blue eyes is Doll Baby. She looks like an angel and she is an angel, but she can be a naughty angel sometimes, although her father won't believe it. Her real name is Frances, but we call her Dolly or Doll.

turns.speaker: WASKI
turns.text: Mother... is Rose going to die?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: No, Waski, she won't die, because we are praying for her.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh, no, ma'am.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well, it's rather interesting about Brother, actually. I realized the remarkable thing he had when he was six weeks old. He looked at me and understood me, he knew exactly who I was. I know it sounds crazy but it's true. He's very remarkable, he was born for the ministry and could move millions, but he doesn't know that yet. I have to warn you about him, he can be very dangerous, there is an evil streak in him, a streak of pure sheer meanness. But at heart Brother is saintly and that is why he was born for the ministry even if he doesn't know it.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: What are you studying now, Mrs. Hillyer?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: More history, Rose.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Are you going to get your degree soon?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well, I am working on my thesis.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: It must be wonderful to be so smart. I don't see how you do it, reading all those books, learning all that stuff.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Rose, you work too hard. Why don't you go sit down somewhere and drink a Co-Cola?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: You're so sweet.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Really, why don't you go sit down somewhere?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I like to work. I don't mind work. It's the least I can do after all you and Mr. Hillyer have done for me.  You're so sweet. There never was nobody like you.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well, you run on now.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yes, Ma'am.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Rose, you're in an awful dither tonight. What's the matter with you, honey, are you sick or something?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: No, ma'am, I'm just fine.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: You look sick if you ask me. I hate to leave you with the dishes and all, but I'm supposed to go to a meeting of the Garden Club this evening.  I'll need the car keys.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well, I think it's charming, Rose.  But don't you think... ah, the skirt is a little tight?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh, no, that's the style. It's meant to be clinging.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yes, Ma'am.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Doll, you and Waski run on, too.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Rose, that scruffy-looking man is out in the yard again.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Mrs. Hillyer, I don't know who he is, I really don't.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I had better call Daddy.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I don't think we ought to discuss this in front of the children.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh... oh... oh! I think... maybe... one of 'em... was Foster... but I don't hardly know him!

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I don't want to go to the dentist.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Be quiet, Rose.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Poor thing. Does the ice help, Rose?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Ohh-hh, a little. Oh-h, I ain't never been to no dentist before. He's gonna kill me, I just know it.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: No, Rose, he'll help you.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I'm not goin' in there, I don't like the looks of it!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Rose, sit down in that chair and be quiet! We're trying to help you, you silly creature, sit in that chair!

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh-hh, ohh-hh, Lord, he's gonna kill me.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Never again, never again...

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I know it was bad, honey. I'm sorry...

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: No more dentists, no more dentists...

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: It'll get better now.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Rose has learned her lesson, haven't you, Rose?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yes, ma'am.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Rose, you're very sick. You're burning up. Rose, can you hear me? Rose?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: What? Wha-at? Mrs. Hillyer?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: You see, Rose? Now that's the kind of dress you ought to wear.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yeah, it's kinda nice.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: You look very pretty in it, Rose. Really, you do.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well, you're real sweet to make it for me.  There never was nobody like you. And you don't need to worry, I ain't goin' out no more.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well, there's no reason you shouldn't go out, Rose... in moderation.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I don't want to. When I was lyin' there in that hospital bed at death's door I says to myself, I ain't goin' out no more. If I ever get outta this, I'll just stay home.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Rose, you don't look well and you haven't eaten a bit of breakfast.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I'm not hungry. I can't eat nothin', I haven't been able to eat since I got fired. I think maybe I'm sick.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well, I... I... I don't know... maybe it was... but no, you can't be sure about a thing like that. It wasn't Billy, I didn't know him.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I know it's embarrassing... but who were you exposed to, dear? ROSE Well, now, Mrs. Hillyer, I... ah-h, that's kinda hard to say.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh-h, Mrs. Hillyer, I... I can't think. I... I'm not really sure.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Rose, really, you shouldn't act like that.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh, I know. But I didn't, really. Honestly, I didn't. There was only one, but he's out of town and leave no forwardin' address.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Rose, you don't have to.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I don't mind.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Don't worry, honey, you'll find something.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I was offered that job as a waitress.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Forget about it, I don't want you working in one of those honky tonks.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: You'll never guess what happened!  I have met Mr. Right! I been with him all day and he loves me, I know he does, he loves me and he's going to marry met Be's practi'cly ast me already!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well... well, that's wonderful, Rose.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: And who do you suppose he is? That policeman who arrested me, the one I bit! He is Mr. Right!

turns.speaker: "SCHOOL-MARM"
turns.text: I... I can explain...

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: I'm looking at this poster, and I'm thinkin', I don't remember seeing films like this when I was in school.

turns.speaker: "SCHOOL-MARM"
turns.text: I was going to tell him.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: What were you gonna say?  Exactly how did you think he was gonna make the leap from dating a sweet, innocent school teacher to an ass-fucking porn star?

turns.speaker: "SCHOOL-MARM"
turns.text: But... I love him.  I do...

turns.speaker: "SCHOOL-MARM"
turns.text: Let me tell him.  Let him decide.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: You're not gonna see him again.

turns.speaker: "SCHOOL-MARM"
turns.text: What... what makes you think you can order me around?!

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Maybe I'm not making myself clear. You're probably the first girl Billy-Boy's ever fallen in love with, and I know for sure you're the first he's slept with.  So, how's he gonna feel...  ... when he finds out that the only first he is for you is the first guy who didn't have to pull out at the last second to get his close-up?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Hasn't he got enough problems, or didn't you notice that's not cream soda on his breath?

turns.speaker: "SCHOOL-MARM"
turns.text: ... okay... you made your point.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Indivisible and inseparable.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Incestuous.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Every person's got their own kinks, beef-cake.  What's wrong, Kittle?  You don't swing?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: What Eve and I wouldn't give to meet up with you on the business end of a daisy chain.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Put up your kickstand, freak.  Start talking, or we're out the door.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: A little birdie whispered in my ear today... about the needle-candy you're chasing.  It's up here...  ... in the old curiosity shop.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: How much?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: I figure, for this information, the usual payment... times ten.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: You think it's that good?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: I'll tell you what... I think it's all you've got.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Well... what can I do?  You've created a dilemma...  And, look at the that. Time's running out.  I wonder... how can I impress upon you just exactly how frustrating this situation is for me?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: You get nothing and like it.  And if we're not blissfully happy with what you tell us, we arrest you just for the fun of it.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Okay, man, okay.  I'm with you.  I... I heard how the shit's arriving...  It's coming in a Lincoln.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: And... ?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: What and?  That's what I got.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: A Lincoln?  What Lincoln?  Lincoln Continental?  Lincoln Mark Five... Six... ?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Now you know what to watch for...

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Am I supposed to take this information and sit up in the hills with a frickin' telescope?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Have I ever steered you wrong?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Cuff'em.  Let's see what these two love birds say once they're sitting in separate cages.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Take her down to the car, and for Christ's sake be careful this time.  Last suspect he took in, butter-fingers dropped her down the stairs.  What a mess.  Why is it we don't appreciate our arms and legs till we've lost the use of them?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Hey, listen... I'll give you something else, Kittle.  Anything. Remember... remember that corpse washed up on Huntington Beach?  It was never identified...

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Who cares?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Alright, wait... there's a dentist in Brentwood peddling morphine...

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Careful she doesn't hit her head on the way.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Come on, don't you screw with her, please!  You... you got to want this: armored car job.  CalTrust Bank. They took two million in cash...

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Read my lips: Zimmermann or nothing.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: We'll take the CalTrust heist, but if it's no good, we will hunt you down, and Billy-Boy will pull out your spine and he will beat you to death with it.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Fair enough.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: This is private property.  This is breaking and entering!

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Just entering.  We'll get to the breaking in a minute.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: You're Zimmermann's calculator, Archie.  All the blood money you had to move around to make this deal, you got to know something.  Maybe they told you, maybe you overheard things you weren't supposed to hear...

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: I'm telling you, you're barking up the wrong tree.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Well, I'm running out of trees, so look me in the eye like a man and tell me you don't know!  Convince me!

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: I don't know.  Fuck off!

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: It's six o'clock.  Time's runaing out.  Decide.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: If I tell you, how do I know you won't just club me and take it back?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: You don't.  It's a gamble.  But, not even in Vegas are you gonna get close to this kind of cash.  This is <U>two million</U>, Archie.  It's not three houses, it's twelve.  It's dreams come true.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Three hundred kilos of White Lady hidden inside a giant bust of Abraham Lincoln.  A parade float.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: What... ?

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Abe Lincoln...

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Kittle...

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Where you been hiding, grease-fist? We've been looking for you.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: What do you want?  I'm clean.  I been clean a long time.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Really?  Is that a fact... ?

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Oh, you fuckers!  You fucking fuckers!  What?  What do you want?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Word is, while the vice cops on the East Coast were standing around playing pocket pool, 300 kilos of heroin got smuggled into New York City.  And, right now it's making a cross-country journey to Hollywood, U.S.A.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Hey now... what the fuck... ?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Again.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Know what he's doing, Benny?  He's trying to jog your memory.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: I don't know what you're talking about, man.  Even if I did, I'm not so crazy I'm gonna cross Zimmermann.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: This scag is enough to keep every junkie from here to the Mexican border high as a kite for the next two years.  You think we're gonna let Zimmermann haul it onto <U>our</U> streets on the Fourth-of-fucking-July!?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Last time Billy-Boy did this, the guy's neck broke...  ... just like that.  Sad in a way. Why is it we don't truly appreciate our arms and legs till we've lost the use of them?

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Alright!  Alright... put me down...

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: It's bone dry out there.  Everybody's hurting.  The stuff floating around's been cut so many times it's like powdered sugar, but Zimnermann's gonna fix it.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: I need the "when" and the "where."

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: I don't know, okay?  All I know is Butch Cassidy's back in town.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: How's your precious little school-marm today?

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: She's fine, as if you cared.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Tell me something... what's a school teacher doing having you meet for breakfast in one of the filthiest parts of downtown skank-ville?  I mean, this is not the place for fine dining, unless looking at prostitutes stimulates your appetite.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Filthy kids go to kindergarten too. What are you saying, anyhow?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Nothing, I guess.  Just an observation.  She's really something special.  You're a lucky fella.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Lay off once, would you?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: What'd I say?

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: It's the way you say it, like there's something more too it.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: She's right.  If you two are doing the horizontal polka, the last thing you want is a thirty-five pound bundle-of-joy stumbling around, knocking over furniture and calling you "daddy."

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Jeez... it's too early in the morning for this.  Leave off.  Here's your paper.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: What, am I supposed to read it while I drive?  Keep a grip on it, alright?

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: You shouldn't litter.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Thank you, concerned citizen.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Give a Hoot.  Don't Pollute.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: I'll give you a fucking hoot if you don't shut up back there.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Just a little, you know... Bicentennial memento.  Nothing special.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Whoa, thanks, man.  These are cool. They'll be collector's items.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Escort everyone's favorite She-Male over here nice and peaceful-like. Let's not have another incident like at the laundromat.  I'll never forget the look on that poor woman's face.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: That wasn't my fault.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Save it.  Just go.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: I... I can't find my seatbelt.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: What do you want me to do about it?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Sons of bitches!

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: We catch 'em, I wanna be first to hurt 'em.  Promise me I get to go first.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: We'll share.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: I can work this.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: No you can't.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Get ready.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Make a hole, Billy-Boy.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: I'd rather you guys didn't do this again.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Move it!

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: This is too fast.  This is <U>way</U> too fast!

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Relax.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: We should slow down.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Hands off the suit, monkey-boy. Close your eyes if you're scared.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Jiminy Christmas.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: I can not even begin to imagine how much that must have hurt.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: I say, fuck 'em.  Let's go.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Well... we shouldn't rush into this, right?  Let's talk about it.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: What are you, Henry friggin' Kissinger all the sudden?

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: I'm just saying...

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: You're just saying nothing!  Tonight is the night.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Yeah, but if we don't sit, they'll take our badges.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: What of it?  Haven't we waited forever... ?  Haven't we, honey?  Haven't we waited long enough to get this scumbag?

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: All I got is being a cop.  What do I do if I'm not that?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: You big, fat sonofabitch, if it weren't for me, you'd still be sitting in the file room where I found you.  And you... Nena... you've still got needle scars from where I pulled you out of.  You of all people...

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: We shoulda been there to back you up. We shoulda!

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Stop blaming yourself.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Ah, jeez, Billy... careful!

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: I got him.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Who's that?  Zimmermann's money-man?

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Where you gonna be?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: It's personal.  We'll hook up at Billy-Boy's pad in an hour.  See ya then.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: No offices are gonna be open today.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Lots of these pencil-pushers work out of their homes.  It's a tax dodge.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Okay, we got... one, two... three...  Two Caddies and Poe's Mustang.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Could be worse.  I don't know how, but I'm sure it could.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Remember those two uniform cops who been giving us such a hard time... ?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: The ones you got in that fist-fight with a couple a weeks ago... ?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: That's them trying to kill us.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Well, they sure know how to hold a grudge.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Look, Kittle... pull over and let me out.  I'll be fine... okay?  How 'bout that... ?  Oh, Lord almighty, listen to me... I don't want to die!!  Lemme out of this coffin!!

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Clench your teeth.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Wh... what... ?!

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Clench your teeth so when we land you don't accidentally bite off your tongue.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: That's sick.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Welcome to Beverly Hills. Wife-swapping Capital of the World.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: What's the plan?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Beats me.  You got a suggestion, feel free to shout it out, genius.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: When you planning to cut back on that?

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: The booze.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: I don't know.  I could quit now if I wanted, I just don't want to.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: I don't know what the problem is. Plenty of great men throughout history got their bravery out of a bottle

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Name one.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Dean Martin.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Entertainers don't count.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Who's been giving you history lessons?  Your bartender?

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Okay, seriously.  What about Napoleon, huh?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: What about him?

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: You've never heard of Napoleon brandy, Mister Smarty-Pants?  How do you think it got its name?

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: They... they shot me.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: They shot us all, kid.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: What day is it?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Same day as before.  I think.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Where we going?

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: We're gonna rain on Zimmermann's parade.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: How you doing back there?

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Feeling great.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Gimmie a butt.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: You don't smoke.

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: I'm not taking a cigarette break, jackass, just give me one!

turns.speaker: KITTLE
turns.text: Happy Independence Day.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Yeah.  Happy Fourth of July.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Why do I always have to sit in back?

turns.speaker: NENA
turns.text: It's just the way things are, kiddo.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Well, I would like to sit in front today.

turns.speaker: NENA
turns.text: It's not gonna happen.

turns.speaker: NENA
turns.text: You been wearing rubbers, Billy-Boy?

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Wha... ?

turns.speaker: NENA
turns.text: Birth control's important.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: What... what kinda thing is that to say?

turns.speaker: NENA
turns.text: You know, the more weight back there, the faster the car goes.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Bullshit.

turns.speaker: NENA
turns.text: You never heard of physics, Einstein? The laws of physics.  The more ballast we keep closer to the rear tires...

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: I'm back here, aren't I?  So, you don't have to make up a buncha lies to make me feel good about it.

turns.speaker: NENA
turns.text: Oh... okay.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: What's mine say?

turns.speaker: NENA
turns.text: "Leo.  The stages of the moon are in alignment, so now is a perfect time for a vigorous regimen of self improvement.  Wash yourself more carefully each morning, stop using pies and cakes as your primary source of nourishment, and quit tucking your shirttails inside your underwear."

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: It doesn't say that.

turns.speaker: NENA
turns.text: No, but it should.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: Hey...

turns.speaker: NENA
turns.text: Forgive me for not ooing cartwheels over commemorative salt and pepper shakers

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: That's him alright.

turns.speaker: NENA
turns.text: It's go time, Billy-B.

turns.speaker: NENA
turns.text: Smooth move, hot-shot.

turns.speaker: BILLY-BOY
turns.text: What was I supposed to do?
